title: 'No Brexit deal tonight' as Boris Johnson scrambles to find agreement
text:

There is no chance of a Brexit deal being agreed tonight, it has been reported.

Boris Johnson ’s hope breakthrough faded just hours before a crunch Brussels showdown.

Less than 24 hours before he was due to meet European Union counterparts, the Prime Minister compared Brexit to climbing Everest - and insisted he was almost at the summit.

European Council President Donald Tusk said today: “The basic foundations of this agreement are ready and theoretically we could accept a deal tomorrow.”

French President Emmanuel Macron also fuelled hopes of a last-minute breakthrough, saying: “I want to believe an agreement is being finalised and that we will be able to endorse it tomorrow.”

But the BBC, Sky and ITV cited Government sources saying a deal tonight was not likely.

(Image: GUILLAUME HORCAJUELO/EPA-EFE/REX)

EU leaders are due to gather from 2pm on Thursday - and UK and bloc negotiators were locked in a race against time as they fought to thrash out a fresh pact which can be agreed at the make-or-break summit.

Downing Street sources said “thorny issues” included arrangements for customs in Northern Ireland and how best to secure “consent” from the province for plans to avoid a hard border with the Republic.

VAT was also thought to be a sticking point as the countdown to Britain’s scheduled exit day on October 31 intensified.

Irish premier Leo Varadkar said: “We have a pathway to a possible deal but there are issues still to be fully resolved.

“First is the issue of consent and democracy, ensuring that any long-term arrangement that applies to Northern Ireland has the democratic assent of the people of Northern Ireland, and second is the whole issue of customs, ensuring that there is no customs border between North and South and no tariffs on trade.”

Mr Johnson’s spokesman admitted there “certainly remain issues to resolve”.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

As negotiations ran down to the wire and teams battled for a last-gasp breakthrough, the fate of any agreement appeared to rest with Northern Ireland’s Democratic Unionist Party, whose support is vital to getting a deal through Parliament.

The party’s leader Arlene Foster and its Westminster chief Nigel Dodds were in and out of Downing Street yesterday as the PM desperately struggled to keep them onside.

It was thought he was checking what last-minute concessions he could offer the EU without losing their crucial backing.

The DUP wants a key role for the Stormont Assembly - which has not sat since January 2017 when the power-sharing executive collapsed - before any new arrangements for Northern Ireland come into force.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

But the EU feared that effectively gave the DUP a veto.

Reports suggested “EU sources” said the party had accepted the latest plans on consent.

But Mrs Foster hit back: “‘EU sources’ are talking nonsense. Discussions continue. Needs to be a sensible deal which unionists and nationalists can support.”

In between meetings with the DUP, Mr Johnson rallied Tory backbenchers in a Commons committee room - and likened Brexit to climbing Mount Everest.

The PM told his MPs: “If you’ll excuse a mountaineering metaphor, we are at the Hillary Step - and the summit, you can see but it’s shrouded in cloud.

“But we can see it and we will get there.”

Tory MP Bim Afolami said there was a “sense of relief in the room that we’re almost there,” adding: “It’s been a long slog.”

(Image: ITV)

The rocky Hillary Step outcrop named after mountaineer Sir Edmund Hillary collapsed in 2015.

Sources also said Mr Johnson compared Brexit to Hollywood blockbuster The Shawshank Redemption in which the hero escapes jail by wading through a tunnel of sewage.

Mr Johnson’s reference to the Hillary Step could, like many of the Prime Minister’s colourful comparisons, ultimately and unwittingly backfire on him.

The 39ft rocky outcrop was located very high on Mount Everest at 28,839ft above sea level, near the summit.

Named after mountaineer Sir Edmund Hillary, who became the first climber to reach the top of the mountain, it was located on the south-east ridge, halfway between the “South Summit” and the true summit.

Online reports say it gave climbers the last real challenge before reaching the top of the mountain via the south-east route.

But it no longer exists, having most likely collapsed in 2015 during a massive earthquake.

Flanked by bodyguards, Mr Johnson scurried away from the 1922 Committee meeting after just eight minutes, telling MPs he had “things to do”.

Earlier, the PM held a 45-minute Cabinet meeting in No10, updating senior ministers on the progress of talks.

“He said there was a chance of securing a good deal but we are not there yet and there remain outstanding issues,” said Mr Johnson’s spokesman.

“Following a positive discussion, Cabinet gave the PM its full support in the Government’s continuing efforts to secure a deal ahead of European Council.”

He also held a series of meetings in No10 with Tory Brexit hardliners.

(Image: WILL OLIVER/EPA-EFE/REX)

Arch-Brexiteer Steve Baker said he would need to see the legal text of a deal before any vote on it.

He added: “If I am not shown the legal text I shall vote no because I haven’t read it.”

Mr Johnson is expected to fly to Brussels at lunchtime today.

But his RAF plane was on standby for a quick dash across the Channel in the early hours if negotiations reached a crucial point.

Even if he manages to secure a fresh Withdrawal Agreement, the PM faces a knife-edge Commons vote to win MPs’ backing.

He has a majority of minus 45 after stripping rebel Conservatives of the party whip and being hit by a series of defections.

If Mr Johnson wins the DUP’s support for a deal, most Tory Brexiteers in its European Research Group would be expected to follow.

He could end up needing the backing of a handful of Labour MPs to finally cross the line.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Sources suggested about a dozen Labour backbenchers from Leave-supporting seats could vote for a deal.

The Commons will vote on Thursday on triggering a rare Saturday sitting of Parliament this weekend, from 9.30am to 2pm.

The last took place in April 1982 after Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands.

If Mr Johnson fails to get a deal through the Commons by 11pm Saturday, he is legally-bound to ask Brussels for a fresh Brexit delay.

He has repeatedly vowed the UK will leave on October 31, “do or die, come what may”.

But Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay today admitted the Tory leader would write to the EU Commission requesting another extension - as previously revealed in documents submitted during a Scottish court challenge.

Mr Barclay told MPs: “I can confirm, as the Prime Minister has repeatedly set out, that firstly the Government will comply with the law, and secondly it will comply with undertakings given to the court in respect of the law.”

The PM’s spokesman insisted: “We’ve always said we will comply with the law but we will be leaving on October 31.”

However, even if the Government succeeds in pushing a deal through Parliament, EU sources believe a short technical extension could be needed beyond Halloween .

A Withdrawal Agreement would need to be signed-off by the European Parliament - and various pieces of legislation need to pass through Parliament.

However, Mr Barclay stressed MPs were able to act speedily when they wanted to - indicating he believed there was still enough time.
description: EU leaders are due to gather from 2pm on Thursday - but a workable agreement has not yet been reached
